name: wheat grain, import from RoW | wheat grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19425/documentation

This data represents the import of one kg of wheat grain from Rest of the World to South Africa.

From transportation of wheat grain from the harbor. 

This activity ends with imported wheat grain at a main harbour in South Africa.The dataset includes transportation to South Africa harbour by freight ship.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

flow.name: wheat grain
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

exchanges.description: Estimated value based on the percentage grain imported of processed (SAGIS, 2017a;SAGIS, 2017b), breakdown by exporting country and distance from exporting country port to Durban Port. The 10-year average grain imports of consumption of 48% was used (SAGIS, 2017b). The breakdown by exporting country was determined using export tonnages reported by country for combined product 100199 (Wheat and meslin, excluding seed for sowing, and durum wheat) and product 100119 (Durum wheat, excluding seed for sowing) for 2015 and 2016 calendar years. Export tonnages was retrieved online from TradeMap (http://www.trademap.org/). The distances were estimated using Ports.com. Exporting countries (ports) applied are as folllows: 35% Russia (Novorossiysk), 14% Germany (Hamburg), 10% Canada (Vancouver), 10% Australia (Fremantle/ Albany/ Port Adelaide), 8% USA (South Louisiana), 7% Argentina (San Martin/San Lorenzo/Rosario), 7% Lithuania (Klaipeda), 6% Ukraine (Yuzhny/Odessa/Chernomorsk) and the remainder Poland (Gdansk/Gdynia). The corresponding ports were identified to be either the designated port for grain exports, or where data was not available, the largest exporting terminal in the region. Reference(s): SAGIS (2017a) Supply and Demand: Marketing Year October 2016 to September 2017, South African Grain Information System. Available at: http://www.sagis.org.za/sd_marketing_year.html. (Accessed April 2017); SAGIS (2017b) Historic Deliveries, Consumption, Imports and Exprts of Wheat, South African Grain Information System. Available at: http://www.sagis.org.za/historical%20prod%20consumption%20imp%20exp.html. (Accessed August 2017)
